answers.answer: Hi.  Since your grandmother's primary tumor is 2 cm in size, she really should have the radiation after the lumpectomy (in accordance to the National Comprehensive Cancer Network or NCCN practice guidelines).  This will indeed help lessen her chances of recurrence.  If your grandmother is in relatively good health and is expected to live for another 10-15 years if not for the cancer, then I really think she should take the option of radiation.  Since her estrogen sensitivity is only 40%, taking femara alone may not be as effective in preventing cancer relapse in the next 10 years, and I would be more assured of preventing recurrence if she had radiation treatment.

question: Hello,My grandmother was diagnosed with breast cancer about a month ago and had a lumpectomy 2 weeks ago.  They also did a biopsy of the sentinel node.  Margins are clear and no other cancer has been found.  She will be starting Femara soon.  She has been seen by two separate oncologists (and members of their teams).  While they both agree on the Femara, they disagree on whether or not she needs to have radiation therapy.  One recommends it while the other says it's an option but doesn't think it's necessary if getting the treatment will affect my grandmother's quality of life.  My grandmother is old-world and just wants her doctors to tell her what is good for her and she will do it.  So, they decision is more or less left up to her family (including me).I lean towards her getting radiation now while my uncle would rather "save it for when it is needed" (since she can only have radiation in the same area once in her life).  Here is the info we have for her:age:  78general health:  good, no dz (other than the cancer), no heart/cholesterol/diabetes problems, expected to live a healthy and long liferemoved breast lump size:  2 cmestrogen sensitivity:  approx. 40% (not sure what this means, but quoting MD who thinks she should have radiation)My understanding is that without radiation, there is a 15-20% chance of reocurrence.  Is this true?  Also, how much would this percentage decrease if she does have radiation now?  I was told that without radiation, she is "good for another 10 years".  What about after the 10 years?  God-willing, she can live past her 80s (my grandfather is well into his 100s).It seems to me that, considering that the side affects of radiation are less compared to other forms of cancer treatment/prevention, the only real issue would be a logistical one and my grandmother's convenience (she will have to go to the MD 5 days a week for 6 weeks).  I think this is worth it, but I'm concerned about the idea that she will not be able to have radiation again later should it re-occur.  Is that enough of a reason to not have it now?I'd appreciate whatever guidance or clarification you can provide in this matter.  Thanks so much!
title: Next Steps for My Grandma
